member.summary: Extends the interface to include the method.

member.name: M:NMock.Syntax.IAutoActionSyntax`1.WillReturn(`0)
member.summary: This is the strongly-typed version of the method. Use this method when the value to return is this value (and not a matcher).
member.remarks: This version of the "Will" methods is used in place of .Will(Return.Value(obj)) when obj is known and should be checked at compile time. The benefit is that the method takes a strongly-typed argument. The drawback is that you can't specify a matcher.

member.name: T:NMock.MockStyle
member.summary: Specifies how a mock object should behave when it is first created.

member.name: F:NMock.MockStyle.Default
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will result in ExpectationExceptions.

member.name: F:NMock.MockStyle.Transparent
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will pass through to the underlying implementation on the class being mocked.

member.name: F:NMock.MockStyle.Stub
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will be ignored. Default values are used for return values (default value of the return type, stub or empty enumerable) and the same value is returned on every call to the same member.

member.name: F:NMock.MockStyle.RecursiveStub
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will be ignored. Default values are used for return values (default value of the return type, stub or empty enumerable) and the same value is returned on every call to the same member.

member.name: M:NMock.Syntax.IStubSyntax`1.Method(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Action{`0}})
member.summary: Creates an expectation for the method specified when the method returns . The arguments are ignored, use the result of this method to specify the expected arguments.
member.param: A method call expression that specifies the expected method.
member.returns: An instance of a class used to specify the parameters.

remarks.note: This overload is chosen by the compiler when the method specified in the action returns .

An expectation created with this method will not use the parameters supplied to the method call. Parameters must be supplied in order for the code to compile. Use the or methods as part of the return type of this method. As an alternative, use the method which will use the parameters supplied to the method as part of the expectation.
The method should not be used from this method. This method is used for return types, therefore a return expectation is not needed.

member.overloads: Creates an expectation for the method specified.
member.example:
In this example, the method returns void.
mock.Expects.One.Method(m=>m.MethodName("IgnoredParam")).With("RealParam");

member.name: M:NMock.Syntax.IStubSyntax`1.Method``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{`0,``0}})
member.summary: Creates an expectation that this method will be called. The arguments are ignored, use the result of this method to specify the expected arguments.
member.param: A method call expression that specifies the expected method.
member.returns: An object used to specify expected arguments or return value.

member.name: M:NMock.Syntax.IStubSyntax`1.MethodWith(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Action{`0}})
member.summary: Creates an expectation for the method specified when the method returns . The arguments are used as the expected values.
member.param: A method call expression that specifies the expected method.
member.returns: An instance of a class used to specify the parameters.

remarks.note: This overload is chosen by the compiler when the method specified in the action returns .
An expectation created with this method will use the parameters supplied to the method call.

member.overloads: Creates an expectation for the method specified.
member.example:
In this example, the method returns void.
mock.Expects.One.MethodWith(m=>m.MethodName("RealParam"));

member.name: M:NMock.Syntax.IMethodSyntax`1.SetProperty``1(System.Func{`0,``0})
member.summary: Creates an expectation that this property will be set to a value specified in the result of this method. The value used in the expression is ignored.
member.param: A set property expression that specifies the property to be set.
member.remarks:
If the property specified in the expression has a getter, a value isn't required in the expression.
mock.Expects.One.SetProperty(p => p.Prop)
instead of
mock.Expects.One.SetProperty(p => p.Prop = "Ignored Value")
The code above only needs to be used in cases where the property is write-only.

member.name: M:NMock.Mock`1.ClearExpectations

member.name: P:NMock.Mock`1.MockObject
member.summary: An object of type to be used whenever the Mocked object is needed.
member.remarks: This property provides access to the proxy that is mocking the actual type. Use this property when a reference to an object that is of the mocked type is needed.

member.name: P:NMock.Mock`1.Expects
member.summary: A syntax property used to access members that specify the number of times an expectation could occur.
member.remarks: This would be considered to be the main property of a class. This property provides access to all other expectation setup methods.
member.example:
In this example:
            
mockis an instance of a .
Expectsrefers to this property.
Oneis the number of times this action is expected.
SetPropertyTois the type of expection.   means the mock expects a property to be set to a value.
mis the variable in our anonymous method that represents the mocked interface or class.
Propis the property on the mocked interface or class that the expectation is for.  It will be set to the value 3.
            
            //create an expectation that the property Prop will be set to 3
            mock.Expects.One.SetPropertyTo(m=>m.Prop=3);
            
            
            View more of this code in the  example.

member.name: P:NMock.Mock`1.IgnoreUnexpectedInvocations
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if this should ignore unexpected invocations to properties, methods, or events.
member.remarks: Use the property to have a Mock ignore calls with no expectations. By default, this works fine for property setters, void methods, and events. Property getters and non-void methods will need to indicate how they will be implemented as they need to return a value.

All classes should then implement interface, to allow interceptors to switch invocation target with instance of another type implementing called interface.

member.name: T:Castle.Core.Logging.TraceLogger
member.summary: The TraceLogger sends all logging to the System.Diagnostics.TraceSource built into the .net framework.
member.remarks:
Logging can be configured in the system.diagnostics configuration section.
If logger doesn't find a source name with a full match it will use source names which match the namespace partially. For example you can configure from all castle components by adding a source name with the name "Castle".
If no portion of the namespace matches the source named "Default" will be used.

member.name: M:Castle.Core.Logging.TraceLogger.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Build a new trace logger based on the named TraceSource
member.param: The name used to locate the best TraceSource. In most cases comes from the using type's fullname.

member.name: M:Castle.Core.Logging.TraceLogger.#ctor(System.String,Castle.Core.Logging.LoggerLevel)
member.summary: Build a new trace logger based on the named TraceSource
member.param: The name used to locate the best TraceSource. In most cases comes from the using type's fullname.
The default logging level at which this source should write messages. In almost all cases this default value will be overridden in the config file.

member.name: M:Castle.Core.Logging.TraceLogger.CreateChildLogger(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new child logger. The name of the child logger is [current-loggers-name].[passed-in-name]
member.param: The Subname of this logger.
member.returns: The New ILogger instance.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IAttributeDisassembler
member.summary: Provides functionality for disassembling instances of attributes to CustomAttributeBuilder form, during the process of emiting new types by Dynamic Proxy.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IAttributeDisassembler.Disassemble(System.Attribute)
member.summary: Disassembles given attribute instance back to corresponding CustomAttributeBuilder.
member.param: An instance of attribute to disassemble
member.returns: corresponding 1 to 1 to given attribute instance, or null reference.
member.remarks: Implementers should return that corresponds to given attribute instance 1 to 1, that is after calling specified constructor with specified arguments, and setting specified properties and fields with values specified we should be able to get an attribute instance identical to the one passed in . Implementer can return null if it wishes to opt out of replicating the attribute. Notice however, that for some cases, like attributes passed explicitly by the user it is illegal to return null, and doing so will result in exception.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.MixinData.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object})
member.summary:
Because we need to cache the types based on the mixed in mixins, we do the following here: - Get all the mixin interfaces - Sort them by full name - Return them by position
The idea is to have reproducible behavior for the case that mixins are registered in different orders. This method is here because it is required

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope
member.summary: Represents the scope of uniquenes of names for types and their members

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope.GetUniqueName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique name based on
member.param: Name suggested by the caller
member.returns: Unique name based on .
member.remarks: Implementers should provide name as closely resembling as possible. Generally if no collision occurs it is suggested to return suggested name, otherwise append sequential suffix. Implementers must return deterministic names, that is when is called twice with the same suggested name, the same returned name should be provided each time. Non-deterministic return values, like appending random suffices will break serialization of proxies.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope.SafeSubScope
member.summary: Returns new, disposable naming scope. It is responsibilty of the caller to make sure that no naming collision with enclosing scope, or other subscopes is possible.
member.returns: New naming scope.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptorSelector
member.summary: Provides an extension point that allows proxies to choose specific interceptors on a per method basis.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptorSelector.SelectInterceptors(System.Type,System.Reflection.MethodInfo,Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptor[])
member.summary: Selects the interceptors that should intercept calls to the given .
member.param: The type declaring the method to intercept.
The method that will be intercepted.
All interceptors registered with the proxy.
member.returns: An array of interceptors to invoke upon calling the .
member.remarks: This method is called only once per proxy instance, upon the first call to the . Either an empty array or null are valid return values to indicate that no interceptor should intercept calls to the method. Although it is not advised, it is legal to return other implementations than these provided in .

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference
member.summary: Handles the deserialization of proxies.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.ResetScope
member.summary: Resets the used for deserialization to a new scope.
member.remarks: This is useful for test cases.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.SetScope(Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope)
member.summary: Resets the used for deserialization to a given .
member.param: The scope to be used for deserialization.
member.remarks: By default, the deserialization process uses a different scope than the rest of the application, which can lead to multiple proxies being generated for the same type. By explicitly setting the deserialization scope to the application's scope, this can be avoided.

member.name: P:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.ModuleScope
member.summary: Gets the used for deserialization.
member.value: As has no way of automatically determining the scope used by the application (and the application might use more than one scope at the same time), uses a dedicated scope instance for deserializing proxy types. This instance can be reset and set to a specific value via and .

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.AttributeDisassembler.InitializeConstructorArgs(System.Type,System.Attribute,System.Reflection.ParameterInfo[])
member.summary: Here we try to match a constructor argument to its value. Since we can't get the values from the assembly, we use some heuristics to get it. a/ we first try to match all the properties on the attributes by name (case insensitive) to the argument b/ if we fail we try to match them by property type, with some smarts about convertions (i,e: can use Guid for string).

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.AttributeDisassembler.ReplaceIfBetterMatch(System.Reflection.ParameterInfo,System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: We have the following rules here. Try to find a matching type, failing that, if the parameter is string, get the first property (under the assumption that we can convert it.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget
member.summary: Exposes means to change target objects of proxies and invocations

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget.ChangeInvocationTarget(System.Object)
member.summary: Changes the target object () of current .
member.param: The new value of target of invocation.
member.remarks: Although the method takes the actual instance must be of type assignable to , otherwise an will be thrown. Also while it's technically legal to pass null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) as , for obvious reasons Dynamic Proxy will not be able to call the intercepted method on such target. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws. Also while it's technically legal to pass proxy itself as , this would create stack overflow. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws.
member.exception: Thrown when is not assignable to the proxied type.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget.ChangeProxyTarget(System.Object)
member.summary: Permanently changes the target object of the proxy. This does not affect target of the current invocation.
member.param: The new value of target of the proxy.
member.remarks: Although the method takes the actual instance must be of type assignable to proxy's target type, otherwise an will be thrown. Also while it's technically legal to pass null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) as , for obvious reasons Dynamic Proxy will not be able to call the intercepted method on such target. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws. Also while it's technically legal to pass proxy itself as , this would create stack overflow. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws.
member.exception: Thrown when is not assignable to the proxied type.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.SaveAssembly
member.summary: Saves the generated assembly with the name and directory information given when this instance was created (or with the and current directory if none was given).

remarks.para: This method stores the generated assembly in the directory passed as part of the module information specified when this instance was constructed (if any, else the current directory is used). If both a strong-named and a weak-named assembly have been generated, it will throw an exception; in this case, use the overload.
If this was created without indicating that the assembly should be saved, this method does nothing.

member.exception: Both a strong-named and a weak-named assembly have been generated.
member.returns: The path of the generated assembly file, or null if no file has been generated.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.SaveAssembly(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves the specified generated assembly with the name and directory information given when this instance was created (or with the and current directory if none was given).
member.param: True if the generated assembly with a strong name should be saved (see ); false if the generated assembly without a strong name should be saved (see .

remarks.para: This method stores the specified generated assembly in the directory passed as part of the module information specified when this instance was constructed (if any, else the current directory is used).
If this was created without indicating that the assembly should be saved, this method does nothing.

member.exception: No assembly has been generated that matches the parameter.
member.returns: The path of the generated assembly file, or null if no file has been generated.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.LoadAssemblyIntoCache(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Loads the generated types from the given assembly into this 's cache.
member.param: The assembly to load types from. This assembly must have been saved via or , or it must have the manually applied.
member.remarks: This method can be used to load previously generated and persisted proxy types from disk into this scope's type cache, eg. in order to avoid the performance hit associated with proxy generation.

member.name: T:Castle.Core.Logging.StreamLogger
member.summary: The Stream Logger class. This class can stream log information to any stream, it is suitable for storing a log file to disk, or to a MemoryStream for testing your components.
member.remarks: This logger is not thread safe.

member.summary: Creates proxy object intercepting calls to members of interface on object with given .
member.typeparam: Type of the interface implemented by which will be proxied.
member.param: The target object, calls to which will be intercepted.
The interceptors called during the invocation of proxied methods.
member.returns: Object proxying calls to members of on object.
member.exception: Thrown when given object is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
Thrown when given array is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
Thrown when given is not an interface type.
Thrown when no default constructor exists on actual type of object.
Thrown when default constructor of actual type of throws an exception.
member.remarks: This method generates new proxy type for each type of , which affects performance. If you don't want to proxy types differently depending on the type of the target use method. member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ProxyGenerator.CreateInterfaceProxyWithoutTarget``1(Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptor)
member.summary: Creates proxy object intercepting calls to members of interface on target object generated at runtime with given .
member.typeparam: Type of the interface which will be proxied.
member.param: The interceptors called during the invocation of proxied methods.
member.returns: Object proxying calls to members of types on generated target object.
member.exception: Thrown when given array is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
Thrown when given is not an interface type.
member.remarks: Since this method uses an empty-shell implementation of interfaces to proxy generated at runtime, the actual implementation of proxied methods must be provided by given implementations. They are responsible for setting return value (and out parameters) on proxied methods. It is also illegal for an interceptor to call , since there's no actual implementation to proceed with. As a result of that also at least one implementation must be provided. This method uses implementation to generate a proxy type. As such caller should expect any type of exception that given implementation may throw.

member.remarks: Since this method uses an empty-shell implementation of to proxy generated at runtime, the actual implementation of proxied methods must be provided by given implementations. They are responsible for setting return value (and out parameters) on proxied methods. It is also illegal for an interceptor to call , since there's no actual implementation to proceed with. This method uses implementation to generate a proxy type. As such caller should expect any type of exception that given implementation may throw.

remarks.para: This could be very useful in cases where the actual target method is based on a generic type definition. In such cases, the instance needs to be able to describe the actual parameter types being used by the current generic type instantiation. member.summary: Modifies a to support intercepting calls to the 'new' operator.
member.param: The assembly to be modified.
The functor that determines which type instantiations should be intercepted.
The filter that determines which host methods will be modified
member.remarks:
The type filter determines the concrete types that should be intercepted at runtime. For example, the following functor code intercepts types named "Foo":
Func<TypeReference, bool> filter = concreteType => concreteType.Name == "Foo";

member.name: M:LinFu.AOP.Cecil.Extensions.NewOperatorInterceptionExtensions.InterceptNewInstances(Mono.Cecil.IReflectionStructureVisitable,System.Func{Mono.Cecil.MethodReference,Mono.Cecil.TypeReference,System.Boolean},System.Func{Mono.Cecil.MethodReference,System.Boolean})

The filter that determines which host methods will be modified
member.remarks:
The type filter determines which concrete types and constructors should be intercepted at runtime. For example, the following functor code intercepts types named "Foo":

member.name: P:LinFu.AOP.Interfaces.IInvocationInfo.ParameterTypes
member.summary: The parameter types for the current target method.

remarks.para: This could be very useful in cases where the actual target method is based on a generic type definition. In such cases, the instance needs to be able to describe the actual parameter types being used by the current generic type instantiation. This property helps users determine which parameter types are actually being used at the time of the method call.

member.name: T:LinFu.Finders.Interfaces.CriteriaType
member.summary: The enumeration that determines how a instance should be handled if the criteria test fails.

member.name: F:LinFu.Finders.Interfaces.CriteriaType.Standard
member.summary: A failure in a criteria test will result in a lower weighted score for a target item.

member.name: F:LinFu.Finders.Interfaces.CriteriaType.Optional
member.summary: A failure in a criteria test will be ignored, and hence, the criteria will be optional.

member.name: F:LinFu.Finders.Interfaces.CriteriaType.Critical
member.summary: A failure in a criteria test will cause all previous and remaining tests against the criteria to fail.
